@TProphet 4/ Caveat for #3 is that follow-on shouldn't have to be at any price, should be at reasonable price, which can be hard to agree on
@TProphet 3/ however, if $ of signaling matters, and company is viable, then investor should follow on with at least some amount.
@TProphet 2/ I think if investor's follow-on is either immaterial in terms of check size or signaling risk, then also ok not to follow on.
@TProphet 1/ if a company is clearly running out of business, then more funding postpones that... so IMO it's not really helping.

@sbyrnes @garrytan Maybe, but there are other proxies for demand besides revenue. E.g. pre-launch, but 500k ppl on waitlist (@RobinhoodApp)
@sbyrnes @garrytan and from my experience, it seems like most (b2b SaaS) startups raise off of traction for Series As.
@sbyrnes @garrytan Markets can overvalue ideas or serial founders... but I think once you're competing on traction, it's a different game.
@garrytan (b/c if you plan to raise again, you can almost always raise when growing 25% monthly, and almost never if growing 10%.)
@garrytan Been thinking about this a lot. It also implies one should take bigger risks. 20% shot at 25% MoM growth > 90% shot at 10% growth.

RT @ssnacks: @lpolovets The argument is broken because it is lost in a tweetstorm.
@calcsam You might save >>1% on your first few offers by seeing good comp data. I've seen founders give 6-10% to eng #1, which is crazy.
@calcsam Also, re: "it's worth a great engineer" -- one value of a good investor w/huge portfolio is comp data.
@calcsam +1. I'm all for a fair market price, which might mean less dilution to founder. I just believe in 1 market price in a given week =)
@calcsam sometimes. It's more about hearing the +20% than the actual number.
@brendanbaker I've met pre DD co's that are great, but poor fit for me. OTOH met perfect fits post DD, but couldn't invest b/c of cap jumps.
@brendanbaker Absolutely. But "somebody" != "right somebody". It's pretty random when there are 30+ companies in a batch, none advertised.
@brendanbaker For investors. When founder sets price + deadline of DD (which is <1 wk away), they incentivize the things mentioned above.
@brendanbaker That's a crapshoot =). Some accelerators list companies pre DD, most don't. And then it's a game of luck, not skill/fit.
@brendanbaker Less diligence. Less relationship building. Smaller checks that are less meaningful to investor. Etc.
@brendanbaker I think the incentive perspective is more important: what do lower caps pre demo day incentivize?
@brendanbaker I like 500 Startups' model: companies often raise at lower cap a few mo's before demo day... but it's not overnight cap jump.
@calcsam Your idea can/does work in practice though. But I guess... why not just try to raise the whole round at 1.1X to keep things simple?
@calcsam Ah, gotcha. Asking #1 means some investors bow out because of that, which makes $X+20% the likely default decision.
@AntarYaami IMO bump should be pre acceptance vs post acceptance... not pre DD vs post DD. Going thru accelerator is what increases value.
@AntarYaami Part of DD value is that it's hard to reach 100s of investors, but 100s will go to DD to see companies "approved" by accelerator
@AntarYaami I think it's like college: ppl often don't use college learnings at work, yet employers love validation from prestigious degree.
@calcsam Do you mean dynamically putting people into buckets post demo day? That can put people off if they land in the wrong bucket =)
@AntarYaami The DD dynamic is more about investors getting rewarded for investing 1 day earlier, even when ability to raise wasn't risky.
@AntarYaami Agree outside of DD, where raising $ gives you breathing room, and that is kind of material (although biz progress is better)
@calcsam 20% bump is roughly immaterial to founder (~1.5% additional marginal dilution), but very material to VC who has to explain to LPs..
@brendanbaker Rephrasing above: if a company can raise $1m in a few days, then fundraising wasn't a risk, so derisking it is not material.

@brendanbaker Very true and a great point. But companies doing this would be funded anyway, so they're just self-selecting away from VCs.
@calcsam That's fair if you think investor $ is fungible. If you don't, then gaming system means you miss out on some great investors.
7/ Just figure out how much $$ you need, have market set price, and stick to that price. Stop trying to game the system -- it'll backfire.
6/ I strongly believe that valuations should be fixed until there are material business developments (MBDs). Demo days are *not* MBDs.
5/ Third, the biggest checks will often be the most involved over next 1-2 years. If anything, they should get a discount, not a mark-up.
4b/ (angel investors don't have this problem and often have non-monetary motives for investing.)
4/ Second, VCs are more valuation sensitive. If you just raised at a 20% lower cap, I'll have to explain to LPs why I had to pay a premium.
3/ First, you're rewarding people for writing smaller checks. That's silly. There's no reason to reward (or punish) that.
2/ This is broken for several reasons:
1/ I've observed a pattern at a few recent demo days: raise $$ from angels just before demo day, raise cap, raise from seed VCs at demo day.

@athomasq Btw, in example above, a $9m is an underbid from the VC's POV, but a great deal from the founder's POV. So it's a win-win.
@athomasq Tons of factors at play. Some VCs target 3x instead of 4x. Others find stuff no one is bidding on. Others use brand to bid lower..
@athomasq $9m is more than what others would pay but actually gets you an expected 5.5X instead of 4X.
@athomasq If everyone is looking for 4X, and consensus is that EV is $32m, but you "know" it's actually $50m, then you offer $9m valuation.
@athomasq I think better risk estimates usually benefit in a slightly different way: being able to pay higher prices.
@athomasq Thought experiment: pay $100 to enter a game. Lose investment 99% of time, win $10k in 10 years 1% of time. Would you play?
@athomasq No, because investor expects ROI in exchange for locking up money. People wouldn't invest just to get EV.

@tanayj @synopsi @rabois @mdudas IIRC, #1 was mission+team (often mentioned together); distant #2 was growth/learning potential or role.
@maxcan @rabois But VCs advocate for startups if a candidate cares more about other things than about pure comp.
@maxcan @rabois I don't know if VCs really advocate for not worrying about money. Prioritization of $ vs other stuff is a personal choice.
@thogge @rabois @tanayj @synopsi @mdudas It's not a binary choice. Not like Google lacks mission. But mission/team are the driving factors.
@tanayj @synopsi @rabois @mdudas I dunno.. makes sense to negotiate at any size co. Also, sometimes people negotiate for less $, more stock.
@calcsam @synopsi @rabois @mdudas True. I also saw reasons that people passed on offers. If went to big co, it was $$; if small co: mission.
@tanayj @synopsi @rabois @mdudas Not 100% sure, but almost certainly yes.
@maxcan @rabois Yup. You can invest capital in many startups, but you can only spend your time at one company at a time.
@synopsi @rabois @mdudas Basically, if you compete with Google on comp, you're going to lose. But competing on mission/work/etc can win.
@synopsi @rabois @mdudas No one mentioned comp (even though sometimes comp was quite strong).
@synopsi @rabois @mdudas *Every single offer* was accepted because a candidate loved the team or the mission or the work.
@synopsi @rabois @mdudas I polled a bunch of founders a few months ago on reason candidates accepted job offers.
@vijayv But if you stay until the startups become big co's and take leadership roles as they grow, then maybe!
@vijayv If you mean working at 10x startups in a row, then it's a crapshoot. If you hit a top 1% one you'll do great, if not you won't.
10/ Join a startup because you believe in the mission, want to work with the founders, want to have an outsized impact within your co, etc.
9/ Similarly, if you joined a startup to maximize earnings, you probably made a mistake.
8/ If you bought a racecar for driving your family around town, then you made a bad decision. That's not one of its strengths.
7/ Criticizing startup comp for being lower than comp at Google is like complaining that a race car isn't family-friendly.
6/ The truth is that you will almost never find all of these attributes in one place.
5/ Jobs are similar: you can optimize for cash comp, total comp, benefits, coworker quality, personal impact, interesting work, etc.
4/ There are very, very rare exceptions that check most of the boxes (Tesla?), but they're... well, exceptional.
3/ For cars, you can pick 3-4 out of: fuel efficient, stylish, high performance, low maintenance, durable, family friendly, etc.
2/ Finding a job is like buying a car: there are trade-offs.

9 of 9/ Not only is it okay to say "I don't know", I think it's actually a best practice for building a company.
8/ Key part of that is asking other smart people what they think, admitting gaps in knowledge, and being open to evolving their plans.
7/ Having gone through the Trough of Sorrow once, they don't want to waste 5+ yrs of their lives on something that's doomed from the start.
6/ Instead of trying to project infallibility, 2nd timers ask about what they might be missing, question and test their assumptions, etc.
5/ (Actually, great first-time founders know these things, too.)
4/ Serial founders know what they are good at, but also know what they're not good at, and know that there's a lot they don't know.
3/ OTOH, serial founders -- esp. those who went through a 5-10 year slog and know the ups and downs of entrepreneurship -- are the opposite.
2/ I've noticed a similar pattern: first time founders often try to demonstrate that they know everything.

3/ OTOH, competitive advantages help you win new customers, but don't necessarily help you retain those customers over time.
2/ High switching costs help you keep existing customers, but don't help you win new customers.
1/ Observation: most people think lock-in and high switching costs are the same as a sustainable competitive advantage. They're not.

7/ A great answer to this question is a big competitive advantage; a poor answer makes progress very hard -- even w/solid founders and idea.

5/ Today, that's no longer the case.
4/ 5+ years ago, if someone wanted to be part of a startup, joining an existing one was much, much easier than raising money for a new one.
3/ In parallel, most job candidates are either risk averse (prefer working at GOOG/FB/etc) or risk seeking (want to work at a startup).
2/ It's easier than ever to raise $500k+ with a good founding team and a reasonable idea.

11/ The End. I'll probably do a blog post about this on http://t.co/9pJibMfxOg in the next week or two.
10/ Summary: making more bets -> lower variance in returns; making better bets or helping companies after investing -> better returns.
9d/ - helping late-stage startups optimize their paths to successful IPOs.
9c/ - helping growing companies grow faster/more efficiently. (Via connections to new customers, domain expertise, etc.)
9b/ - helping distressed companies exit for a little more. (e.g. so that they return 2/3 of your initial investments instead of 1/3)
9a/ OTOH, "value add" can mean many things:
8b/ If chance of a company becoming a unicorn is 1%, but 2.5% of your picks are unicorns, that's going to be *huge* for your portfolio.
8a/ Picking better = being a little more likely to pick unicorns or being a little less likely to pick companies that will fail.
7/ I think the real returns are in 1) learning to pick new investments more effectively or 2) adding more value to existing investments.
6/ There are only so many great co's each year. Maybe there are 5 unicorns annually, or maybe 20. But it's not 50 or 100. (Well, not yet.)
5b/ Investing X into 5 funds w/30 portfolio companies each is not super different from investing 5X in one fund w/150 portfolio co's.
5a/ I wonder how much LPs care about diversification within a fund if they invest in many funds simultaneously.
4/ If company exits follow a statistical distribution -> more companies in portfolio will reduce variance but won't affect expected returns.
3/ I've been thinking about portfolio construction a lot over the last few months and have a slightly different view:
2/ I agree with much of it, and really respect that Dave puts his ideas out there.
1/ Really liked @davemcclure's latest blog post about portfolio design. https://t.co/IRlC0WIZ8l

(The end.)
10/ Finally, to be honest, if someone gave me a chance to take $3m off the table for a small portion of my stake, that'd be hard to refuse.
9/ It's like playing a version of roulette where #8 pays off 90x. You might not get #8 on first few tries, but you should def. keep playing.
8/ So in that respect, I think this specific liquidity event was a failure, but the overall strategy of offering liquidity is good/viable.
7/ It's huge if 90% of liq. events don't impact final outcome but last 10% lead to founders growing companies to $10b vs. selling for $300m.
6/ Similarly, it can be a good investing decision to offer founders liquidity if that's a deciding factor for deal.
5/ That said, VC is governed by power laws. For example, it's okay to make 10 binary bets if 9 are terrible but the 10th returns 50x.
4/ Founder liquidity should be based on traction w/users (being a product w/a great future), not traction w/investors (being a hot deal).
3/ IMO it's not fair to employees or investors or customers if founders take liquidity when the future of a company is very uncertain.
2/ Personally, I'm bummed by the founder liquidity event that was in the news recently.

6/ Unfortunately, time/resources are limited. Better to pick something good enough and run with it than to be paralyzed by indecision.
5/ For step #4, main problem is FOMO. Hard to commit to going all-in if you're afraid there are better approaches you haven't tried yet.
4/ For step #1, common problems are dismissing ideas too early, or avoiding ideas that seem hard/unpleasant (or where you lack experience).
3/ This works well for picking growth channels, finding product/market fit, UX design, etc. Challenges usually lie in first or last step.
2/ 1) brainstorm promising approaches; 2) run cheap experiments; 3) measure results; 4) go all-in on most promising approach.

@OCVC Guesstimating.
9/ But I agree w/@msuster: posting links and nothing else is a poor use of Twitter and its capabilities. Talk to people. Be genuine. Opine.
8/ Obviously this is a simple metric. It also matters how frequently you post, what time of day, etc.
7/ If you have 1.3m followers and you can only muster 100 faves and retweets, you're doing something wrong.
6/ On the other hand, some examples of poor product-market fit: Thomas Friedman (.05%), Maureer Dowd (.05)%, NY Times (.001%-.003%)
5/ I hate to say it, but also: Justin Bieber (.2%-.5%)
4/ Examples of engagement rates showing high product-market fit: @hunterwalk (.1%-.3%), @levie (.3%-.7%), @StartupLJackson (.2%-.5%)
3/ High F+R rates mean that you're posting what your followers hoped you'd post. Low F+R means your content is for you, not your audience.
2/ I think Faves+Retweets (F+R) relative to # of Followers is a measure of product/market fit for tweets.
